input: The N.B.A. players union is considering an appeal of the seven-game suspensions given to Ron Artest and Stephen Jackson for legal issues. Each player was suspended by the league Saturday without pay and was scheduled to miss the first seven games of next season. Artest would lose a little more than $470,000 in salary, about $50,000 more than Jackson.Jackson released a statement through the Golden State Warriors saying he accepted his suspension. But the union, comparing the penalties with other recent suspensions given to players for off-the-court reasons, may take action. Artest pleaded no contest in May to a misdemeanor domestic violence charge that stemmed from a dispute with his wife on March 5. Jackson pleaded guilty last month to a felony count of criminal recklessness for firing a gun outside an Indianapolis strip club last fall, when he was with the Indiana Pacers. The union has 30 days from Saturday to file an appeal to be heard by an arbitrator.
syn: The National Basketball Association's players association is contemplating an appeal of the seven-game suspensions handed to Ron Artest and Stephen Jackson due to legal troubles. Each athlete was suspended by the association last Saturday without remuneration and is expected to miss the season's first seven matches. Artest stands to forfeit slightly over $470,000 in earnings, approximately $50,000 more than Jackson. Jackson, via a press release from the Golden State Warriors, stated he acknowledged his suspension. However, the association, evaluating these punishments against other recent disciplinary actions for off-field incidents, might initiate an appeal process. Artest entered a no contest plea in May to a misdemeanor charge of domestic violence arising from a March 5 incident with his spouse. Jackson admitted guilt last month to a felony charge of criminal recklessness for discharging a firearm outside a strip club in Indianapolis the previous autumn, during his time with the Indiana Pacers. The association has a 30-day window from last Saturday to submit an appeal, which would then be reviewed by an impartial arbitrator.

input: If you hang around on web-related mailing lists long enough, you start getting the idea that the future is full of metadata. Now, this metadata may or may not be XML, or it may or may not be RDF or OWL or a dozen other technologies with impressive-sounding words like “ontology” in their names. It may or may not be the long-dreamt-of (and often derided) “Semantic Web.” In fact, it may or may not be a dozen different buzzwords, and it may or may not be a good thing. But whatever the future is, it will definitely be full of metadata; on this the experts agree.    To my mind there’s a problem with this: the argument always seems to depend on technologies which don’t exist or aren’t quite ready yet, so it always falls back to talking about how things will be “in the future,” which may never get here. Luckily, there's an easy way to add oodles of metadata to your documents right this minute, without having to learn anything more complicated than trusty old HTML 4.01. If it catches on, “the future” might get here a lot sooner than expected.
syn:
If you linger on web-focused discussion groups long enough, you begin understanding that the horizon is brimming with metadata. This metadata might or might not be XML, or it might or might not utilize RDF, OWL, or various other frameworks with sophisticated terminologies such as "ontology" in their titles. It could or could not embody the often-hypothesized (and frequently mocked) "Semantic Web." In essence, it could or might not incorporate numerous buzzwords, and its benefits are debatable. However, one thing is certain: metadata will saturate the future; in this, the specialists concur.
To me, there’s an issue with this scenario: the debate constantly relies on solutions which haven't materialized or are not fully operational yet, hence it perennially shifts to speculations about how circumstances will unfold "in the future," a point that might never arrive. Fortunately, there's a straightforward method to infuse tons of metadata into your content immediately, without needing to master anything more obscure than the reliable HTML 4.01. If this approach becomes widespread, "the future" may arrive much more swiftly than anticipated.

input: If you hang around on web-related mailing lists long enough, you start getting the idea that the future is full of metadata. Now, this metadata may or may not be XML, or it may or may not be RDF or OWL or a dozen other technologies with impressive-sounding words like “ontology” in their names. It may or may not be the long-dreamt-of (and often derided) “Semantic Web.” In fact, it may or may not be a dozen different buzzwords, and it may or may not be a good thing. But whatever the future is, it will definitely be full of metadata; on this the experts agree.    To my mind there’s a problem with this: the argument always seems to depend on technologies which don’t exist or aren’t quite ready yet, so it always falls back to talking about how things will be “in the future,” which may never get here. Luckily, there's an easy way to add oodles of metadata to your documents right this minute, without having to learn anything more complicated than trusty old HTML 4.01. If it catches on, “the future” might get here a lot sooner than expected.
syn: If you linger in tech-focused discussion forums often enough, you begin to doubt that the past was devoid of metadata. Now, this metadata might or not be CSV, or it might not be JSON or YAML or numerous other methods with mundane titles like “data table” in their descriptions. It might not be the once-hyped (and frequently mocked) “Static Web.” In truth, it might not be countless outdated terms, and it might not be a bad thing. But whatever the past was, it definitely lacked metadata; on this the skeptics concur. To my view, there’s a solution to this: the debate always appears to hinge on technologies which have vanished or are obsolete, so it constantly returns to discussing how things were “in the past,” which might always remain behind us. Fortunately, there's a difficult way to remove vast amounts of metadata from your files right this second, without having to forget anything as simple as modern HTML5. If it falls out of favor, “the past” might stay further away than expected.
